articles.headline: Tightening Race Comes as Abrupt Blow to Romney Team
articles.snippet: After arriving in South Carolina fresh off of what seemed to be two victories in a row, Mitt Romney could leave as the winner of only one of the first three nominating contests.
articles.abstract: After arriving in South Carolina fresh off of what seemed to be two victories in a row, Mitt Romney could leave as the winner of only one of the first three nominating contests.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — With Mitt Romney facing the biggest challenge to his presidential aspirations since he announced his candidacy, his aides acknowledged Friday what seemed unthinkable just seven days ago: He could lose the South Carolina primary.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Ashley Parker and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Justices’ Texas Redistricting Ruling Likely to Help G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court blocked election maps proposed by a lower court, and said the court had not paid enough deference to a plan drawn up by Texas’ Republican-controlled Legislature.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court blocked election maps proposed by a lower court, and said the court had not paid enough deference to a plan drawn up by Texas’ Republican-controlled Legislature.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday rejected elections maps drawn by a federal court in Texas that had favored Democratic candidates there.

articles.headline: Founder of Shuttered Web Site Sought Limelight
articles.snippet: The founder of Megaupload, which was shut down after a raid by the police in New Zealand on Friday, went by the name Kim Dotcom and made no secret of his exploits.
articles.abstract: The founder of Megaupload, which was shut down after a raid by the police in New Zealand on Friday, went by the name Kim Dotcom and made no secret of his exploits.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Some uninvited guests showed up at Kim Dotcom’s mansion outside Auckland, New Zealand, on Friday: the police, in two helicopters.

articles.headline: The Dawn of Lower Pay on Wall St.
articles.snippet: A capped cash bonus for Morgan Stanley’s employees is another sign of more restrained compensation practices by banks.
articles.abstract: A capped cash bonus for Morgan Stanley’s employees is another sign of more restrained compensation practices by banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day of reckoning may be at hand.

articles.headline: In Fire Investigation, Regulators Say They Found No Defect in Volt
articles.snippet: A federal review concludes that modifications planned by General Motors in the plug-in hybrid car are sufficient to reduce the risk of a fire after a severe crash.
articles.abstract: A federal review concludes that modifications planned by General Motors in the plug-in hybrid car are sufficient to reduce the risk of a fire after a severe crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal safety regulators on Friday closed their investigation into the Chevrolet Volt, saying that they found no evidence of a defect and that plug-in vehicles posed no greater fire risk after a crash than gasoline-powered ones. Still, analysts say that General Motors faces a challenge to rebuild consumer confidence in the car and that related safety concerns could hurt overall acceptance of the growing number of electrified vehicles coming on the market.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Obama Vow on Exports Is on Track, With Help
articles.snippet: President Obama’s plan to double American exports in five years is on track. Exports are now about $180 billion a month, up from $140 billion a month two years ago.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s plan to double American exports in five years is on track. Exports are now about $180 billion a month, up from $140 billion a month two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, President Obama popped a surprise into his State of the Union address: His administration would double American exports in five years, helping to create two million jobs.

articles.headline: Central Bank Becomes an Unlikely Hero in Euro Crisis
articles.snippet: Banks have used quiet emergency loans from the European Central Bank, which has resisted buying up government debt in its own right, to come to their governments’ rescue.
articles.abstract: Banks have used quiet emergency loans from the European Central Bank, which has resisted buying up government debt in its own right, to come to their governments’ rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Throughout the month, countries caught in the eye of the European financial storm, including Italy, Spain and France, have repeatedly defied expectations, selling big batches of bonds to the public at interest rates significantly lower than investors demanded at the height of the euro crisis late last year.

articles.headline: For Gingrich, Wives Always at Center of Career
articles.snippet: Friends and colleagues say that for all his bombast, Newt Gingrich has leaned on his wives — including Marianne, his second, in 1996 — to help project his vision of himself.
articles.abstract: Friends and colleagues say that for all his bombast, Newt Gingrich has leaned on his wives — including Marianne, his second, in 1996 — to help project his vision of himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Newt Gingrich was House speaker, lawmakers would routinely arrive at his elegant suite in the Capitol and find an unexpected adviser sitting on the couch: his wife, Marianne.

articles.headline: A Raucous Hazing at a Wall St. Fraternity
articles.snippet: Kappa Beta Phi, an exclusive Wall Street fraternity, attracted big-name bankers, hedge fund billionaires and private equity titans to its 80th annual black-tie dinner and induction ceremony.
articles.abstract: Kappa Beta Phi, an exclusive Wall Street fraternity, attracted big-name bankers, hedge fund billionaires and private equity titans to its 80th annual black-tie dinner and induction ceremony.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated |

articles.headline: Antipiracy Case Sends Shivers Through Some Legitimate Storage Sites
articles.snippet: YouSendIt, Dropbox, and services from Amazon and Google market themselves as ways to store content. But they are ideal for anyone looking to illegitimately share copyrighted video and audio files.
articles.abstract: YouSendIt, Dropbox, and services from Amazon and Google market themselves as ways to store content. But they are ideal for anyone looking to illegitimately share copyrighted video and audio files.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If Megaupload is guilty, then who among its brethren is innocent?
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy

articles.headline: Blacks Face Bias in Bankruptcy, Study Suggests
articles.snippet: A new survey found that lawyers were more likely to steer whites to Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code and blacks to the more expensive Chapter 13.
articles.abstract: A new survey found that lawyers were more likely to steer whites to Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code and blacks to the more expensive Chapter 13.
articles.lead_paragraph: Blacks are about twice as likely as whites to wind up in the more onerous and costly form of consumer bankruptcy as they try to dig out from their debts, a new study has found.

articles.headline: Obama to Draw an Economic Line in State of the Union
articles.snippet: President Obama will use his election-year address to argue that it is the role of government to promote a prosperous and equitable society, setting a stark contrast between parties.
articles.abstract: President Obama will use his election-year address to argue that it is the role of government to promote a prosperous and equitable society, setting a stark contrast between parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use his election-year State of the Union address on Tuesday to argue that it is government’s role to promote a prosperous and equitable society, drawing a stark contrast between the parties in a time of deep economic uncertainty.

articles.headline: How the U.S. Lost Out on iPhone Work
articles.snippet: Building Apple’s iPhone in the United States would demand much more than hiring Americans — it would require transforming the national and global economies.
articles.abstract: Building Apple’s iPhone in the United States would demand much more than hiring Americans — it would require transforming the national and global economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Barack Obama joined Silicon Valley’s top luminaries for dinner in California last February, each guest was asked to come with a question for the president.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: In a Romney Believer, Private Equity’s Risks and Rewards
articles.snippet: The merits of private equity firms, like Marc J. Leder’s Sun Capital, have come into question again because of Mitt Romney’s time at the firm Bain Capital.
articles.abstract: The merits of private equity firms, like Marc J. Leder’s Sun Capital, have come into question again because of Mitt Romney’s time at the firm Bain Capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was, the gossip pages would later report, the talk of the Hamptons — a midsummer night’s bacchanal in the playground of the 1 percent.

articles.headline: Hazard Insurance With Its Own Perils
articles.snippet: A costly type of coverage, imposed on home buyers who have let insurance lapse, is the subject of a widening investigation in New York State.
articles.abstract: A costly type of coverage, imposed on home buyers who have let insurance lapse, is the subject of a widening investigation in New York State.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE of the richest and most secretive sources of profit in the mortgage business is coming under scrutiny.

articles.headline: Gingrich Wins South Carolina Primary, Upending G.O.P. Race
articles.snippet: Newt Gingrich’s showing brought to the fore questions about whether Mitt Romney, presumed the front-runner, could win over conservatives, Tea Party supporters and evangelical Christians.
articles.abstract: Newt Gingrich’s showing brought to the fore questions about whether Mitt Romney, presumed the front-runner, could win over conservatives, Tea Party supporters and evangelical Christians.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Surprising his rivals and scrambling the Republican race for the presidency, Newt Gingrich won the pivotal South Carolina primary Saturday, just 10 days after a distant finish in New Hampshire left the impression that his candidacy was all but dead.

articles.headline: Fresh Doubts About Republican Contest
articles.snippet: Republican voters, after delivering three different winners in the first three stops in the nominating contest, are in no rush to settle on their nominee.
articles.abstract: Republican voters, after delivering three different winners in the first three stops in the nominating contest, are in no rush to settle on their nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — For Mitt Romney, the South Carolina primary was not just a defeat, though it was most emphatically that. It was also where his campaign confronted the prospect it had most hoped to avoid: a dominant, surging and energized rival.

articles.headline: Greek Talks Hit a Snag Over Rates
articles.snippet: In negotiations on restructuring Greece’s debt, the country and its private creditors disagreed over how much interest the new bonds would pay.
articles.abstract: In negotiations on restructuring Greece’s debt, the country and its private creditors disagreed over how much interest the new bonds would pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Talks between Greece and its private sector creditors over restructuring its debt hit a snag over the weekend over how large an interest rate the new bonds would pay.

articles.headline: Murdoch’s Trusted Outsider Takes a Larger Role
articles.snippet: Amid the scandal at the company’s British newspaper unit, Chase Carey, News Corporation’s president, presents a steady and less polarizing figure.
articles.abstract: Amid the scandal at the company’s British newspaper unit, Chase Carey, News Corporation’s president, presents a steady and less polarizing figure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last August, as News Corporation scrambled to contain a phone-hacking scandal at its British newspaper unit, Chase Carey, the company’s president and chief operating officer, proposed an idea to his boss, Rupert Murdoch: buy back $5 billion worth of stock.

articles.headline: Cameras May Open Up the Board Room to Hackers
articles.snippet: Businesses spend billions each year beefing up security, but they rarely consider the vulnerability of their videoconferencing equipment.
articles.abstract: Businesses spend billions each year beefing up security, but they rarely consider the vulnerability of their videoconferencing equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One afternoon this month, a hacker took a tour of a dozen conference rooms around the globe via equipment that most every company has in those rooms; videoconferencing equipment.

articles.headline: How Esquire Survived Publishing’s Dark Days
articles.snippet: David Granger, Esquire’s editor in chief, departed from standard design templates and modernized the magazine, helping to revive a publication many had left for dead.
articles.abstract: David Granger, Esquire’s editor in chief, departed from standard design templates and modernized the magazine, helping to revive a publication many had left for dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Esquire magazine, a monument to male vitality, seemed about to keel over in 2009. Famous for laying down a much-followed literary track with an article in 1966 by Gay Talese titled “Frank Sinatra Has a Cold,” the magazine found itself gasping for breath and fighting for survival.

articles.headline: The Film Archivist of Legendary Football Preps for Game Day
articles.snippet: N.F.L. Films documents and promotes the National Football League, makes money for the organization and uses its signature style to turn each week’s games into epic battles.
articles.abstract: N.F.L. Films documents and promotes the National Football League, makes money for the organization and uses its signature style to turn each week’s games into epic battles.
articles.lead_paragraph: When N.F.L. Films put a microphone on the Denver Broncos’ surprise star Tim Tebow during a game against the Chicago Bears last month, it knew that every one of its television partners would want a piece of the audio and video of the quarterback.

articles.headline: Pakistan Court Widens Role, Stirring Fears for Stability
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s Supreme Court has inserted itself as the third player in a bruising confrontation between military and civilian leaders at a time when Pakistan faces a dizzying array of threats.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s Supreme Court has inserted itself as the third player in a bruising confrontation between military and civilian leaders at a time when Pakistan faces a dizzying array of threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Once they were heroes, cloaked justices at the vanguard of a powerful revolt against military rule in Pakistan, buoyed by pugnacious lawyers and an adoring public. But now Pakistan’s Supreme Court is waging a campaign of judicial activism that has pitted it against an elected civilian government, in a legal fight that many Pakistanis fear could damage their fragile democracy and open the door to a fresh military intervention.

articles.headline: Bowing to Critics and Market Forces, RIM’s Co-Chiefs Step Aside
articles.snippet: Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis are stepping down at a time when investors wonder whether RIM has the ability to compete in the rapidly changing markets for smartphones.
articles.abstract: Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis are stepping down at a time when investors wonder whether RIM has the ability to compete in the rapidly changing markets for smartphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Jim Balsillie and Mike Lazaridis, who made the BlackBerry a leading business tool but then presided over its precipitous decline, said they would step down on Monday as co-chairmen and co-chief executives of Research in Motion.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Ventures Into Florida, a State Harder to Pigeonhole
articles.snippet: Florida more closely resembles the rest of the country in its diversity, its multiplicity of media markets and its voter base.
articles.abstract: Florida more closely resembles the rest of the country in its diversity, its multiplicity of media markets and its voter base.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — After three bruising contests that each produced different winners, the Republican nominating contest has moved to a state that is much more like the rest of America in its diversity, its multiplicity of media markets and its voter base, which is less likely to be swayed by the family values issues that played a dominant role in prior contests in Iowa and South Carolina.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Gingrich and Romney Trade Jabs as G.O.P. Race Rolls On
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney, facing a restive Republican Party, on Monday warned of the prospect of an “October surprise” if Newt Gingrich emerged as the party’s presidential nominee.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney, facing a restive Republican Party, on Monday warned of the prospect of an “October surprise” if Newt Gingrich emerged as the party’s presidential nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney, facing a restive Republican Party and a resurgent Newt Gingrich, opened a combative new phase of the presidential campaign on Monday and warned of the prospect of an “October surprise” if Mr. Gingrich emerged as the party’s nominee.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: More Lockouts as Companies Battle Unions
articles.snippet: Many Americans know about the highly publicized lockouts in professional sports. But they are increasingly imposed in less visible industries as well.
articles.abstract: Many Americans know about the highly publicized lockouts in professional sports. But they are increasingly imposed in less visible industries as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s unionized workers, buffeted by layoffs and stagnating wages, face another phenomenon that is increasingly throwing them on the defensive: lockouts.

articles.headline: For Giffords, House Comeback Is One Too Many
articles.snippet: In a video released online, Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona said she was stepping down to focus on her recovery after being shot in the head in an assassination attempt last year.
articles.abstract: In a video released online, Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona said she was stepping down to focus on her recovery after being shot in the head in an assassination attempt last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who was shot in the head in an assassination attempt last year, signaled that returning to Congress, something she desperately longed to do, was in the realm of the possible.
